text: Does reaction time depend on tactile feedback?

As you recall, in lesson 1.2, you measured your reaction time using a ruler, comparing your dominant and non-dominant hand. Today we will conduct a similar experiment to investigate how tactile information impacts reaction time (in other words, how being able to feel the ruler with our fingertips impacts how fast we are at catching it?).
If you need a reminder on how to conduct the experiment, please watch this video.
Follow these steps:
1. Decide who is the Dropper and who is the Catcher.

2. The catcher should extend their hand with the index finger and thumb about 1 cm apart. The dropper should hold the ruler at the top such that the catcher has their thumb and index fingers on either side of the zero cm mark.
3. When the catcher says they are ready. the dropper should count up, in their head, to a number between 3 and 5 (use a different number each time). When the number is reached, they drop the ruler.
4. Catcher catches the ruler as fast as they can. Ignore any times the ruler falls on the ground.
5. Enter the ruler cm value closest to Catcherâ€™s pinch point in the table below (you should first drag the table to your worksheet).
6. Repeat steps 2-5 five times.
7. Repeat the process while the catcher is wearing a winter glove.
Drag the following tables into your workspace and use them to record and calculate your results.
Use the table below to convert drop distance (in cm) to time (in milliseconds, which is thousands of a second):
Discuss the following question with your partner and enter your answers in your workspace:
How did wearing a glove affect your reaction time? Why?
PBS News Hour story
Answer the following question after watching the first 3 minutes of the PBS News Hour story
What stood out to you in the video? List at least 3 things in your workspace.
Design an improved gripper
Create a model on paper or a whiteboard to communicate how information about touch/pressure can be incorporated into the design of the gripper. Some things to consider:
1. How would you measure the pressure applied by the gripper on objects?
2. How would touch/pressure information impact the opening/closing of the gripper?
Make sure to label your model. When you're done, take a picture of your model and upload it to your workspace as an image tile.
Reflection
At the end of the activity, please record your current thinking and learning in your Learning journal (see Reflection tab).
